captions.text:
Good morning Hank, it's Tuesday. As you can
tell from the grey speckled walls behind me,

I have found myself, in a stunning turn of
events, in an airport. I've actually been

stuck in the airport for a couple hours, Hank,
because my flight is delayed, and also because
I love airports!

But anyway Hank, I've been thinking about
The Art Assignment. One Art Assignment in

particular, Jace Clayton's The Quietest Place.
For those of you who don't know, The Art Assignment's

a cool show produced by PBS about contemporary
arts, starring my wife, and to a much lesser
extent, myself.

Jace's assignment was for us to take a walk
until we found the quietest place within walking

distance. Right now I can hear two separate
TVs and some children.

And quiet is an interesting thing to talk
about on YouTube because attention has become

so fractured on the internet that there is
no longer room in YouTube videos for ANY silence.

Like Hank, I go back and I watch our videos
from 2007 with the jump cuts that are really,

really slow. And this space between the jump
cuts is just absolutely unbearable. Like in

those 3 silent frames, I think to myself,
"I might not survive until the end of this
video."

And in the many hundreds of responses to Jace
Clayton's Art Assignment I saw this again,

and again. People would be walking to their
quietest places, as I am now, and they would
talk the entire time.

It's only getting louder; this isn't working
at all.

The other thing I noticed, Hank, is that people's
quietest places are incredibly loud. Usually

it was loud with nature sounds, which is fascinating,
because it means on some level, and I think

this is true, we don't think of nature sounds
as being, like, sounds.

We think of them as kind of a loud-quiet.
No, this won't work, I can still hear the
TV.

Anyway, it all made me think about on the
internet, and maybe even outside of it, quiet

can feel kind of discomforting. Just to get
even through a few seconds of quiet requires

this intensity of focus that we're not used
to having to summon.

You know who knows the quietest place in an
airport? TSA employees on a break.

Okay, Hank, here we are, as far as I can tell,
the quietest place in the entire Indianapolis

International Airport, where by gate A4, the
carpet looks like this, and now Hank, together,

we are going to enjoy and/or suffer through
a minute of silence together, alone with our
thoughts.

I can hear so much more than I could when
I sat down.
Hank, happy VidCon, I'll see you on Friday.

comments.text:
Each November 11th at 11am, Canadians observe two minutes of silence to 
mark Remembrance Day. The official national ceremonies are held at the 
National War Memorial in Ottawa, and are televised for the rest of Canada 
to participate if they are so inclined.

Being silent doesn't seem that odd to me, but something on television with 
two minutes of silence is a little spooky.﻿

comments.author: Libby Pugh

comments.text:
I actually don't understand why people feel uncomfortable in silence. When 
there is complete silence, your mind is able to think without distraction. 
Personally, I prefer to spend time inside my own head, getting to know 
myself and thinking deeply on subjects that I normally would be too 
distracted to think about. Even if it gets a little uncomfortable, the 
silence lets you confront the things that make you uncomfortable and will 
help you to become more used to the feel, so the feel of uncomfort stops 
sneaking up on you like that. Besides, its way more interesting in my head 
most of the times.﻿

comments.text:
I saw a channel once where every one of her like 100 videos or something 
was just 9+ seconds of her staring at the camera in silence. It was 
interesting, weird, a bit uncomfortable, but most of all enthralling. What 
was most upsetting though were her comments about (presumably dudes) being 
"aroused," comments like "she's hot" or "really cute." I was hoping to see 
first of all some genuine confusion (as that was clearly the emotion(?) or 
group of emotions she meant to evoke) and maybe hopefully some thoughtful 
discourse on what it all meant but nope just "i fap to this."
Ugggh sometimes I hate comments.﻿

comments.author: Shine Chin

comments.text:
Lovely video John I really enjoyed it. I as well have pondered about this 
topic. It reminds me if the song Car Radio by Twenty One Pilots. Though it 
is a rap song and this is an intellectual vlogyish youtube video. They both 
state that "Sometimes quiet is violent". Silence gets us thinking about 
things that matter and very deep thoughts. Occasionally, these thoughts 
lead to us becoming paranoid. I believe that silence scares us now a days 
is because we are focused living for now (which is not necessarily a bad 
thing), and when the silence creeps up it has us tricked that its all over 
and we shouldn't be wasting those seconds of our short lives. This is all 
reasonable thinking, but I agree with you John that we should all learn to 
appreciate the quiet a little more. In my opinion, it will lessen stress 
from our busy lives.﻿

comments.author: Joan XW Chen

comments.text:
By talking about how people talk the entire time while trying to find their 
quietest place while trying to find your quietest place, you have in fact 
talked the entire time while trying to find your quietest place. 

Acoustic ecology is an interesting area of study in that way; yes, your 
intuition is correct that people find natural sounds, to a certain extent 
regardless how loud they are as a loud form of quiet, while manmade sounds 
are more commonly considered noise pollution of the presumably otherwise 
natural environment. On the contrary, anyone whose attention has been drawn 
to this fact will be more apt to consider the cacophonic sounds that your 
natural surroundings are likely to produce in the same way that you are 
affected by artificial cacophonies. Neat, huh?﻿

comments.author: Laru Horan

comments.text:
This video's topic is something I notice and contemplate on a fairly 
regular basis as a university student (a status being upgraded to 
Instructor this Fall semester, YUS!)

I grew up poor. Like, really poor and the mentality of being frugal with my 
money has persisted into my adult life, despite having disposable income 
enough to spend without tragic consequences such as not eating. As such, I 
avoid luxury items like iPods or MP3 players and for a long time, smart 
phones because neither of those things were things I could eat or things 
that would provide me warmth in the winter. Compound this with not really 
having friends to begin with, I got quite used to walking here and there 
without "noise". This was especially true when I could still run -- when I 
was doing 30-75 minute runs, it was the most peaceful time of my life, 
contrasting all the bad stuff going on. Just me, the trail in the forest, 
focusing on my breathing and taking one more step.

Fast forward 10 years and I'm walking to and from class and an alarming 
number of people have their heads bowed in reverence to their digital deity 
and/or have headphones/ear buds plugged into their ears, almost constantly 
trying to avoid a moment of prolonged silence.

Silence is fantastic. I feel like allowing myself time everyday to focus on 
just re-organizing my thoughts is like tidying up your office space or 
de-frag'ing your computer. I can reach out into my "mind palace", to steal 
a phrase from Sherlock (although mine's more like a "mind studio 
apartment"), and readily access the stuff I regularly take inventory of 
during those moments of silence and it's what I think has helped me succeed 
as a student. At least academically. Again, I've probably failed as a human 
being in respect to being social.﻿
